thread.title: Shhhh: Don’t tell anyone, but UGA is giving Ryan Seacrest an honorary degree
thread.title_full: Shhhh: Don’t tell anyone, but UGA is giving Ryan Seacrest an honorary degree | savannahnow.com

author: Walter C. Jones | Morris News Service
title: Shhhh: Don’t tell anyone, but UGA is giving Ryan Seacrest an honorary degree
text:
Photos Ryan Seacrest SPECIAL OFFER FOR NEW READERS 99 cent digital subscription to savannahnow.com

SIGN UP FOR SUBSCRIBER BENEFITS As a Savannah Morning News / savannahnow.com subscriber, you're eligible for members-only discounts. Download your coupons now. By By Walter C. Jones | Morris News Service ATLANTA – University of Georgia President Jere Morehead is asking the Board of Regents for permission to give an honorary degree to Ryan Seacrest, but the school refuses to provide any details in advance.
Seacrest, the host of television shows like “Gladiators 2000,” “Keeping up with the Kardashians,” and “American Idol,” studied briefly at UGA but left for Hollywood at age 19.
But university officials won’t say why they’ve decided to recognize the Dunwoody native’s professional achievements.
“We are delighted to present Ryan Seacrest to the Board of Regents as a candidate for this honor,” Morehead in a statement from his office to reporters. “Once the Board of Regents votes on this item, we will be happy to provide additional details.”
The request won committee approve Tuesday and comes before the full board today.
No one will say what the honor is or why he deserves it.
Stephanie Schupska, public relations coordinator for the UGA News Service, said, “That’s all they want to say right now.”
Generally, universities present honorary doctorates to people of outstanding professional or humanitarian accomplishments. Often, they are awarded during graduation ceremonies, and many schools use the awards as a way to lure prominent figures to serve as graduation speakers.
The university’s own website says, “the honorary degree is the highest recognition that the University of Georgia can bestow and is therefore not lightly given. It is intended to honor a person who has a sustained record of achievements of a lasting significance.”
Criteria include “broad contributions to society … The prime and controlling consideration should be excellence.”
Seacrest would join the ranks of former Atlanta Mayor Andrew Young, CNN founder Ted Turner and civil-rights attorney Vernon Jones.
The item is listed on the agenda for the regents two-day meeting that wraps up Wednesday at Kennesaw State University. Schools have to get the board’s approval to award honorary degrees, which is usually just a formality.
They are usually listed on the board’s agenda that is made public the Friday before every monthly meeting. In this case, the item was headlined “Honorary Degree Requests: Clayton State University.” Underneath is a sentence about degrees Clayton State seeks for Leonard Moreland and Marcia Taylor. The next sentence says Morehead seeks one for Seacrest.
When and where it will be approved is also a secret.
Regents meetings are intricately choreographed and timed to the minute. Power Point presentations are polished and rehearsed, and unscripted discussions are infrequent even during consideration of controversial matters, other than occasional friendly banter. So, university presidents tend to avoid making public information before they have presented to the board.
